importantArticles.headline: On Thursday, American Airlines pulled its full-year guidance, echoing moves by carriers such as Southwest Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Alaska Air.  United Airlines has been more creative by issuing an outlook for a stable economy, and another for a tariff-induced recession.  American’s results contained another key piece of information: There is “significant weakness” in demand coming from travelers who book through indirect channels such as online portals.
importantArticles.title: Airline Results Suggest Less Wealthy Americans Are Already Feeling Tariffs

importantArticles.title: Stock Rally Powers On as Alphabet Up in Late Hours: Markets Wrap

importantArticles.headline: CHICAGO (Reuters) -Southwest Airlines became the latest U.S. carrier on Wednesday to withdraw its financial forecast as President Donald Trump's trade war has created the biggest uncertainty for the industry since the COVID-19 pandemic.  With the trade war raising the prospect of slower economic growth and higher inflation, both tourists and corporations are sitting tight, leading to a pullback in travel spending.  Southwest said it is not able to reaffirm its previous forecast of $1.7 billion in earnings before interest and taxes in 2025 and about $3.8 billion in 2026.
importantArticles.title: Southwest Airlines drops forecast as US trade war shakes industry

importantArticles.headline: American Airlines pulled its full-year guidance as economic uncertainty plagues the industry.
importantArticles.title: American becomes latest airline to pull guidance as trade war clouds demand outlook

importantArticles.headline: DALLAS (AP) — Southwest Airlines Co. (LUV) on Wednesday reported a loss of $149 million in its first quarter. The Dallas-based company said it had a loss of 26 cents per share. Losses, adjusted for non-recurring costs, came to 13 cents per share.
importantArticles.title: Southwest: Q1 Earnings Snapshot

Historically, airlines have been a bad sector to invest in during a recession.

importantArticles.headline: Southwest Airlines was sued on Wednesday by Utah parents who said their 4-year-old son suffered second-degree burns to his buttocks when a careless flight attendant spilled boiling hot coffee on him.  Ryan Wong and Kamrie Wong also accused other flight attendants of being unapologetic for the September 19, 2024, incident and failing to get proper medical help.  Southwest did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
importantArticles.title: Southwest Airlines sued over spilled coffee on 4-year-old boy: 'It's so hot!'

importantArticles.headline: Jobless claim filings inched up by 4,000 to 223,000 for the week ending April 5, the Labor Department said Thursday.  Weekly applications for jobless benefits are considered a proxy for layoffs, and have mostly ping-ponged between 200,000 and 250,000 for the past few years.
importantArticles.title: US jobless benefit applications rise modestly as labor market remains largely unfazed by trade war

importantArticles.headline: Delta Air Lines (NYSE: DAL) kicked off earnings season with a whimper, but the airline's relatively benign outlook was far better than some investors had anticipated.  The results provided a lift to the entire sector, with carriers including Southwest Airlines (NYSE: LUV) up as much as 5.3% at the open.  The stocks gave back some of those gains as the morning continued, but Southwest was still up 2% as of 11 a.m. ET.
importantArticles.title: Why Delta's So-So Results Are Pushing Airline Stocks Higher Today

importantArticles.headline: (Bloomberg) -- With crude prices plunging below $60 a barrel, consumers who count fuel as their single biggest expense are rushing to lock in supplies. More than 25 million barrels of options contracts on the Brent benchmark traded in structures that protect buyers from price gains this week. The activity reflected consumer hedging that allows airlines, truckers and shipping companies to lock in lower fuel costs, according to people involved in the market. Industrial consumers of oil often use d
importantArticles.title: Airlines and shippers pounce on oil plunge to lock in prices

importantArticles.headline: The credit rating agency adds that Southwest's lack of progress towards margin improvement and higher capital deployment may drive a negative rating action.  Last month, Southwest Airlines announced its plans to start charging some customers for checked bags, marking a departure from its passenger-friendly policies, which Fitch believes could risk eroding its competitive strength relative to its peers.  Fitch said it affirmed Southwest's long-term Issuer Default Rating, which is its outlook on the airlines' ability to meet its financial obligations, at "BBB+".
importantArticles.title: Fitch downgrades Southwest Airlines outlook to negative

importantArticles.headline: The stock market was experiencing its biggest one-day declines in several years on Thursday in the wake of President Trump's tariff announcements.  Not only will the tariffs affect over 180 countries around the world, but for the most part, they were also far worse than experts had anticipated.  The tech-heavy Nasdaq was down 5.5%, and the small-cap Russell 2000 index fell by 6% and is now in bear market territory because it is over 20% below its previous high.
importantArticles.title: Why Are Airline and Cruise Line Stocks Getting Crushed by Tariffs?

importantArticles.headline: An assertive set of recommendation downgrades of airline stocks by a researcher was a major factor in the decline of Southwest Airlines (NYSE: LUV) stock on Tuesday.  Of the four carriers that received a chop, Southwest was one of only two that was demoted to underperform, or sell.  The note covered the stocks of five airlines, four of which received recommendation downgrades.
